attributes.title: Starting School: a large-scale start of school assessment within the ‘Born in Bradford’ longitudinal cohort

summary.value: This registration contains two supplementary files for the paper: Starting School: a large-scale start of school assessment within the ‘Born in Bradford’ longitudinal cohort. The two documents registered are 1) A copy of the feedback document given to teachers following the assessments and 2) The dataset used to produce the histograms in the paper (Figures 1-4).

data.name: Starting School Feedback document for teachers.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Starting School Feedback document for teachers.pdf

registration_responses.summary: This registration contains two supplementary files for the paper: Starting School: a large-scale start of school assessment within the ‘Born in Bradford’ longitudinal cohort. The two documents registered are 1) A copy of the feedback document given to teachers following the assessments and 2) The dataset used to produce the histograms in the paper (Figures 1-4).

uploader.file_name: Starting School Feedback document for teachers.pdf

attributes.title: Helmet Efficacy to Reduce Head & Neck Injury and Mortality in Motorcycle Crashes (EAST)

summary.value:
This review aims to investigate the efficacy of helmet use in adult motorcycle riders in preventing injury and death i.. Additionally, we intend to examine whether the presence of universal helmet laws similarly impact the rates of morbidity and mortality in this population. 

This is an update to a previous systematic review of helmet efficacy in reducing death and injury in adult motorcycle riders. The objective is to rigorously apply GRADE methodology in order to address the question of whether helmet use and helmet laws are efficacious in reducing morbidity and mortality from motorcycle crashes. This is an important issue, as many states continue to have either partial or no helmet laws in place and death and injury rates associated with motorcycle collisions, particularly brain-related injuries, remain a significant problem. 

This systematic review is an update, with new methods,  of: 
MacLeod, J. B. A., DiGiacomo, J. C., & Tinkoff, G. (2010). An Evidence-Based Review: Helmet Efficacy to Reduce Head Injury and Mortality in Motorcycle Crashes: EAST Practice Management Guidelines. Journal of Trauma and Acute Care Surgery, 69(5), 1101-1111. doi:10.1097/TA.0b013e3181f8a9cc

This registration contains support documents

data.name: EAST Practice Guideline on Motorcycle Helmet Use  - Base Search Strategy for MEDLINE - Draft.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: EAST Practice Guideline on Motorcycle Helmet Use  - Base Search Strategy for MEDLINE - Draft.pdf

attributes.title: The Role of Metacognition in Differentiating Dementia and Depression in the Population of Sixty Years and Over
attributes.description: This project aims to explore whether metacognitive beliefs differ among patient with dementia and depression and also if they differ, how this difference affects their executive functioning abilities.

q1.value: The Role of Metacognition in Differentiating Dementia and Depression in the Population of Sixty Years and Over

q2.value: Vasfiye Derya Sen, Elvin Dogutepe, Prof. Ufuk Can, Ass. Prof. Seda Kibaroglu

q3.value: This project aims to explore whether metacognitive beliefs differ among patient with dementia and depression and also if they differ, how this difference affects their executive functioning abilities.

q4.value:
1) Patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and early dementia (ED) group will have much more negative metacognitive beliefs about cognitive confidence and cognitive awareness when compared to patients with depression; however, patients with depression will have much more negative metacognitive beliefs about worry and uncontrollability.

2) This difference in metacognitive beliefs will have a different effect on executive functioning abilities. While the metacognitive beliefs that patients with MCI and ED have might negatively affect their memory-related performances, the metacognitive beliefs that patients with depression have might negatively affect their attention-related performances. 

3) About half of the patients with MCI and DE are expected to have anosognosia based on the previous researches in the literature. Anosognosia is considered as a moderator in the relationship between the pathology that the patients of this study have and their executive functioning abilities. Therefore, the disruption on the performances related to executive functioning abilities that the patients without anosognosia are expected to be lower. In fact, patients’ awareness of their illness is predicted to have a negative effect on their cognitive performance.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Cross-sectional Study Design
Three conditions: patients with MCI and ED, but without depression, patients with depression, but without MCI and ED, and healthy controls.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Patients will be directed through M.D.s in the Neurology Department at Baskent Hospital. Participation will be based on voluntariness of patients. Patients will be assigned to the groups according to Clinical Dementia Rating Scale, Montreal Cognitive Assessment, and Beck Depression Inventory or the Geriatric Depression Scale.

Inclusion criteria for clinical groups are as follows: Patients aged 60 and over, having only mild cognitive impairment, early dementia or depression, being the mother tongue of Turkish, not having any other psychological/neurological diagnosis, being the first referral to the clinic related to the diagnosis and not receiving treatment, lack of other medical diagnoses and medication known to affect cognitive processes, lack of corrected vision and hearing impairment.

Exclusions criteria for clinical groups are: Being under the age of 60, having other forms of dementia (such as dementia in Parkinson's disease), having other forms of depression (such as post-traumatic stress disorder), and inability to complete the given forms.

Inclusion criteria for the healthy control group are: No memory complaints, no psychological/neurological diagnosis, no other medical diagnoses and medication known to affect cognitive processes, no corrected vision and hearing impairment.

Relatives of the participants will be determined as the person who can evaluate the patient's cognitive processes as objectively as possible. This person might be the patient's spouse, child, caregiver, or close friend. Information will be gathered from the patient and/or companion at the hospital visit to determine the relative who will complete one part of the Anosognosia Questionnaire for Dementia (for relatives).

q13.value: 156 patients will be calculated by using G-Power Analysis for this study (52 patients for each group). Moreover, 156 relatives of patient will be needed to complete the Anosognosia Questionnaire for Dementia.

question.value:
1) Metacognitive beliefs that the patients have will be measured by the Metacognitive Questionnaire-30

2) Executive functioning abilities related to memory and attention will be measured by the Stroop Task and the Auditory Verbal Learning Test

3) Anosognosia as a moderator variable will be assessed by the Anosognosia Questionnaire for Dementia.

Since the study has multiple dependent variables, MANOVA was determined as one of the proper options to apply. The effect of metacognitive beliefs that the patients have as an interaction effect on the relation between the pathologies and executive functioning abilities will be also assessed by using SPSS or/and JASP.

While the metacognitive beliefs that patients with MCI and ED have might negatively affect their memory-related performances, the metacognitive beliefs that patients with depression have might negatively affect their attention-related performances. 

3) About half of the patients with MCI and DE are expected to have anosognosia based on the previous researches in the literature. Anosognosia is considered as a moderator in the relationship between the pathology that the patients of this study have and their executive functioning abilities. Therefore, the disruption on the performances related to executive functioning abilities that the patients without anosognosia are expected to be lower. attributes.title: What is the impact of pro/synbiotics supplementation on management of type 2 diabetes risk factors in adults with polycystic ovarian syndrome: a meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials

q1.value: Pro/synbiotics supplementation for management of type 2 diabetes risk factors in adults with polycystic ovarian syndrome: a meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials

q3.value: Evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) suggests that supplementation with pro/synbiotics may offer beneficial effects on control of glucose homeostasis in polycystic ovary syndrome patients. Our purpose is to conduct a meta-analysis of RCTs to evaluate the effects of pro/synbiotics supplementation on glucose homeostasis in polycystic ovary syndrome patients (PCOS).

q4.value: If supplementation with pro/synbiotics may offer beneficial effects on control of glucose homeostasis in polycystic ovary syndrome patients, glucose homeostasis index  will be a significant difference compared to the control group.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value:
Study Selection 
Relevant articles will be included if they fulfilled the following inclusion criteria. (1) A randomized controlled trial with a parallel or cross-over design. (2) Adult (≥18 years old) population with polycystic ovary syndrome. (3) Sufficient reporting of anthropometric indices in both the intervention and placebo groups. (4) Reported mean ± standard deviation (SD) or standard error (SE) for at least one parameter [fasting blood glucose (FBG), homeostatic model assessment for insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), quantitative insulin sensitivity check index (QUICKI), insulin] in both the control and treatment groups at baseline and at the end of trial. (5) Use of probiotics in any formulations or in dairy products and any species/strains/treatment/dose of live probiotics or synbiotics. The following exclusion criteria will be also applied: (1) non-randomized clinical trials; (2) uncontrolled studies (lack of a placebo control); (3) reported duplicate data; or (4) reviews, letters or case reports.  

Data Sources and Searches
This meta-analysis will be conducted and reported in accordance with the guidelines of the Cochrane Handbook and the relevant criteria from the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement . The Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cochranelibrary/search; to 1 December 2019), Medline (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed; 1945 to 1 December 2019), Web of Science (http://isiknowledge.com; 1900 to 1 December 2019), and Google Scholar (https://scholar.google.com/; to 1 December 2019) were subjected to a systematic search of the published literature. The strategy presented in Supplementary Table 1 to identify RCTs. The search will be not language restricted. The final search will be conducted on December 1, 2019. 

Data Extraction and Quality Assessment
Y.Y.S., and F.W.T. independently will extract the following data from the 15 studies deem eligible for inclusion: study design, first author’s name, publication year, mean age and BMI of the participants, number of participants, sample size, duration of intervention, general details of the intervention (type, form, dose of probiotics), details of both the experimental intervention (type of oral supplementation, dosage, number of species) and the control and outcomes (FBG, insulin, QUICKI, HOMA-IR).

The overall certainty of the evidence will be evaluated using the grading of recommendations assessment, development, and evaluation (GRADE) approach , where evidence will be graded as very low, low, moderate, or high-certainty quality. Evidence obtained from RCTs receives an initial grade of high. Scores can be downgraded based on study limitations (assessed by the Cochrane risk-of-bias tool), inconsistency (substantial unexplained heterogeneity, I2 > 50%, P < 0.05), indirectness (presence of factors that limit the generalizability of the results), imprecision (95% CI for the pooled effect estimates that are wide or overlap minimally important differences for benefit or harm), and publication bias (significant evidence of small-study effects). The Cochrane risk-of-bias tool was used to assess the risk of bias of each individual study via a domain-based evaluation. The following criteria will be assessed by the two authors: random sequence generation (selection bias), allocation concealment (selection bias), blinding of participants and personnel (performance bias), blinding of the outcome assessment (detection bias), incomplete outcome data (due to the amount, nature or handling of incomplete outcome data), selective reporting (reporting bias) and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by a third adjudicator.    
                        
Data Synthesis and Analysis 
The meta-analysis will be conducted using RevMan version 5.3 (Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, UK) and Comprehensive Meta-Analysis 2.0 (Biostat, Englewood, NJ, USA). For all PCOS symptoms, mean differences (MDs) in the outcome data will be used in the meta-analysis if they will be reported by at least three studies. For outcomes that could be measured using different units, the reported effects will be presented as standardized mean differences (SMD). The meta-analysis also implemented a random-effect model based on the detected heterogeneity among studies . The effect sizes are presented as mean differences with 95% confidence intervals, and P values <0.05 will be considered statistically significant. Heterogeneity will be explored quantitatively using Cochran's Q-test [26] and I-square statistics (I2) . Here, I2 values of <25%, 25% to <75% and >75% will be considered to indicate low, moderate and high heterogeneity, respectively. When the I2 value wwill be ≥25%, the possible reasons for heterogeneity were investigated using the following methods: (1) subgroup analysis (according to the number of bacterial species and source of strain isolation); (2) sensitivity analysis, to identify which trial caused the heterogeneity and how each trial contribute to the overall analysis; and (3) random effect meta-regression, to identify which trials caused heterogeneity and how the trials contribute to the overall analysis. The mean change and SD for each index will be used to evaluate the effect size of the intervention. For studies that do not report the index, the SD of the mean difference will be calculated using the following formula: SD2 = [(SD baseline2 + SD final2) - (2×R×SD baseline×SD final)], where the correlation coefficient (R) will be set at 0.5. Begg’s rank correlation test and Egger’s regression intercept test will be applied to each included trial to evaluate publication bias . Again, a P value <0.05 will be considered to indicate significance.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Study Selection 
Relevant articles were included if they fulfilled the following inclusion criteria. (1) A randomized controlled trial with a parallel or cross-over design. (2) Adult (≥18 years old) population with polycystic ovary syndrome. (3) Sufficient reporting of anthropometric indices in both the intervention and placebo groups. (4) Reported mean ± standard deviation (SD) or standard error (SE) for at least one parameter [fasting blood glucose (FBG), homeostatic model assessment for insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), quantitative insulin sensitivity check index (QUICKI), insulin] in both the control and treatment groups at baseline and at the end of trial. (5) Use of probiotics in any formulations or in dairy products and any species/strains/treatment/dose of live probiotics or synbiotics. The following exclusion criteria were also applied: (1) non-randomized clinical trials; (2) uncontrolled studies (lack of a placebo control); (3) reported duplicate data; or (4) reviews, letters or case reports.  

Data Sources and Searches
This meta-analysis was conducted and reported in accordance with the guidelines of the Cochrane Handbook and the relevant criteria from the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement . The Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cochranelibrary/search; to 1 December 2019), Medline (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed; 1945 to 1 December 2019), Web of Science (http://isiknowledge.com; 1900 to 1 December 2019), and Google Scholar (https://scholar.google.com/; to 1 December 2019) were subjected to a systematic search of the published literature. The strategy presented in Supplementary Table 1 to identify RCTs. The search was not language restricted. The final search was conducted on December 1, 2019. 

Data Extraction and Quality Assessment
Y.Y.S., and F.W.T. independently extracted the following data from the 15 studies deemed eligible for inclusion: study design, first author’s name, publication year, mean age and BMI of the participants, number of participants, sample size, duration of intervention, general details of the intervention (type, form, dose of probiotics), details of both the experimental intervention (type of oral supplementation, dosage, number of species) and the control and outcomes (FBG, insulin, QUICKI, HOMA-IR).

The overall certainty of the evidence was evaluated using the grading of recommendations assessment, development, and evaluation (GRADE) approach , where evidence was graded as very low, low, moderate, or high-certainty quality. Evidence obtained from RCTs receives an initial grade of high. Scores can be downgraded based on study limitations (assessed by the Cochrane risk-of-bias tool), inconsistency (substantial unexplained heterogeneity, I2 > 50%, P < 0.05), indirectness (presence of factors that limit the generalizability of the results), imprecision (95% CI for the pooled effect estimates that are wide or overlap minimally important differences for benefit or harm), and publication bias (significant evidence of small-study effects). The Cochrane risk-of-bias tool was used to assess the risk of bias of each individual study via a domain-based evaluation. The following criteria were assessed by the two authors: random sequence generation (selection bias), allocation concealment (selection bias), blinding of participants and personnel (performance bias), blinding of the outcome assessment (detection bias), incomplete outcome data (due to the amount, nature or handling of incomplete outcome data), selective reporting (reporting bias) and other bias. Disagreements were resolved by a third adjudicator.

q14.value: All available studies will be included.

question.value: Not applicable in the context of a meta-analysis
fasting blood glucose (FBG), homeostatic model assessment for insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), quantitative insulin sensitivity check index (QUICKI), insulin

he meta-analysis will be conducted using RevMan version 5.3 (Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, UK) and Comprehensive Meta-Analysis 2.0 (Biostat, Englewood, NJ, USA). For all PCOS symptoms, mean differences (MDs) in the outcome data will be used in the meta-analysis if they will be reported by at least three studies. For outcomes that could be measured using different units, the reported effects will be presented as standardized mean differences (SMD). The meta-analysis also implement a random-effect model based on the detected heterogeneity among studies [25]. The effect sizes are presented as mean differences with 95% confidence intervals, and P values <0.05 are considered statistically significant. Heterogeneity will be explored quantitatively using Cochran's Q-test [26] and I-square statistics (I2) [27]. Here, I2 values of <25%, 25% to <75% and >75% are considered to indicate low, moderate and high heterogeneity, respectively. When the I2 value are ≥25%, the possible reasons for heterogeneity are investigated using the following methods: (1) subgroup analysis (according to the number of bacterial species and source of strain isolation); (2) sensitivity analysis, to identify which trial caused the heterogeneity and how each trial contribute to the overall analysis; and (3) random effect meta-regression, to identify which trials cause heterogeneity and how the trials contribute to the overall analysis [28]. The mean change and SD for each index will be used to evaluate the effect size of the intervention. For studies that do not report the index, the SD of the mean difference is calculated using the following formula: SD2 = [(SD baseline2 + SD final2) - (2×R×SD baseline×SD final)], where the correlation coefficient (R) is set at 0.5. Begg’s rank correlation test and Egger’s regression intercept test are applied to each included trial to evaluate publication bias [29-31]. Again, a P value <0.05 is considered to indicate significance.

Data Sources and Searches
This meta-analysis was conducted and reported in accordance with the guidelines of the Cochrane Handbook and the relevant criteria from the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement . The Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cochranelibrary/search; to 1 December 2019), Medline (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed; 1945 to 1 December 2019), Web of Science (http://isiknowledge.com; 1900 to 1 December 2019), and Google Scholar (https://scholar.google.com/; to 1 December 2019) were subjected to a systematic search of the published literature. The strategy presented in Supplementary Table 1 to identify RCTs. The search was not language restricted. The final search was conducted on December 1, 2019. 

Data Extraction and Quality Assessment
Y.Y.S., and F.W.T. independently extracted the following data from the 15 studies deemed eligible for inclusion: study design, first author’s name, publication year, mean age and BMI of the participants, number of participants, sample size, duration of intervention, general details of the intervention (type, form, dose of probiotics), details of both the experimental intervention (type of oral supplementation, dosage, number of species) and the control and outcomes (FBG, insulin, QUICKI, HOMA-IR).

The overall certainty of the evidence was evaluated using the grading of recommendations assessment, development, and evaluation (GRADE) approach , where evidence was graded as very low, low, moderate, or high-certainty quality. Evidence obtained from RCTs receives an initial grade of high. Scores can be downgraded based on study limitations (assessed by the Cochrane risk-of-bias tool), inconsistency (substantial unexplained heterogeneity, I2 > 50%, P < 0.05), indirectness (presence of factors that limit the generalizability of the results), imprecision (95% CI for the pooled effect estimates that are wide or overlap minimally important differences for benefit or harm), and publication bias (significant evidence of small-study effects). The Cochrane risk-of-bias tool was used to assess the risk of bias of each individual study via a domain-based evaluation. The following criteria were assessed by the two authors: random sequence generation (selection bias), allocation concealment (selection bias), blinding of participants and personnel (performance bias), blinding of the outcome assessment (detection bias), incomplete outcome data (due to the amount, nature or handling of incomplete outcome data), selective reporting (reporting bias) and other bias. Disagreements were resolved by a third adjudicator.
registration_responses.q16.question: Not applicable in the context of a meta-analysis
registration_responses.q17.question: fasting blood glucose (FBG), homeostatic model assessment for insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), quantitative insulin sensitivity check index (QUICKI), insulin
registration_responses.q19.question: he meta-analysis will be conducted using RevMan version 5.3 (Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, UK) and Comprehensive Meta-Analysis 2.0 (Biostat, Englewood, NJ, USA). For all PCOS symptoms, mean differences (MDs) in the outcome data will be used in the meta-analysis if they will be reported by at least three studies. For outcomes that could be measured using different units, the reported effects will be presented as standardized mean differences (SMD). The meta-analysis also implement a random-effect model based on the detected heterogeneity among studies [25]. The effect sizes are presented as mean differences with 95% confidence intervals, and P values <0.05 are considered statistically significant. Heterogeneity will be explored quantitatively using Cochran's Q-test [26] and I-square statistics (I2) [27]. Here, I2 values of <25%, 25% to <75% and >75% are considered to indicate low, moderate and high heterogeneity, respectively. When the I2 value are ≥25%, the possible reasons for heterogeneity are investigated using the following methods: (1) subgroup analysis (according to the number of bacterial species and source of strain isolation); (2) sensitivity analysis, to identify which trial caused the heterogeneity and how each trial contribute to the overall analysis; and (3) random effect meta-regression, to identify which trials cause heterogeneity and how the trials contribute to the overall analysis [28]. The mean change and SD for each index will be used to evaluate the effect size of the intervention. For studies that do not report the index, the SD of the mean difference is calculated using the following formula: SD2 = [(SD baseline2 + SD final2) - (2×R×SD baseline×SD final)], where the correlation coefficient (R) is set at 0.5. Begg’s rank correlation test and Egger’s regression intercept test are applied to each included trial to evaluate publication bias [29-31]. Again, a P value <0.05 is considered to indicate significance.

attributes.title: Effects of manipulating probability of reinforcement on competition for food and body mass in a small flock of European starlings (Sturnus vulgaris) foraging from operant feeding stations under closed economy.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Food insecurity in starlings: Effects of manipulating probability of reinforcement on competition for food and body mass in a small flock of European starlings (Sturnus vulgaris) foraging from operant feeding stations under closed economy.

other.value:
We will conduct secondary analyses to test the mechanisms responsible for increases in body mass under food insecurity. We hypothesise that the starlings will gain body mass under food insecurity by reducing their energy expenditure and becoming more energetically efficient rather than by eating more.

We hypothesise that when the probability of reinforcement is reduced from 1.0 (food security) to 0.3 (food insecurity) the following specific changes will occur:
5.	The total amount of food eaten per day will decrease
6.	The overall energetic efficiency (i.e. body mass maintained per unit of food consumed) of the flock will increase
7.	The proportion of the day spent perching will increase
8.	The energy density of guano will decrease

To test these hypotheses, we will measure and calculate the following additional dependent variables:
•	Daily food consumption (g) – measured by weighing the food hoppers from the two feeding stations present in the aviary once daily and deducting any food collected in the spill trays.
•	Energetic efficiency will be calculated as total dawn body mass of the birds in the flock divided by total food consumption the previous day.
•	The proportion of the day spent perching will be measured by counting the number of birds perching on the high rope perch (0-6) at 5-minute intervals between dawn and dusk.
•	The energy density of guano will be measured via bomb calorimetry on dried, homogenised guano samples collected once daily from the aviary. Two replicate samples will be collected per day.

Hypotheses 5-8 will be tested with the following analyses:
5.	Total mass of food eaten per day
- Unit of analysis: total mass per day for the flock
- Model: total.mass ~ experimental.condition

6.	Energetic efficiency :
- Unit of analysis: energetic efficiency per day for the flock
- Model: energetic.efficiency ~ experimental.condition

7.	Proportion of the day spent perching
- Unit of analysis: number of birds perching per sample point
- Model: number.perching ~ experimental.condition + (1|day/hour)

8.	Energy density of guano:
- Unit of analysis = two replicate samples per day
- Model: energy.density ~ experimental.condition + (1|day)

In addition to testing the effect of experimental condition on competition for food, we will also explore whether the steepness of the dominance hierarchy increases under food insecurity.

In addition to testing the overall effect of experimental condition on amount of perching, we will also explore whether food insecure birds change their pattern of roosting within the day
If the predicted main effects of experimental condition are found, we will conduct exploratory analyses of how all the measured variables change over the 14 days of food insecurity.

We will attempt to measure song as an additional behavioural indicator of energy expenditure. If we succeed in measuring song in the aviary, we will conduct exploratory analyses of the effects of probability of reinforcement on various metrics of song production.

If we have time to collect data on a final period of food security, we will explore whether the measured variables revert to their baseline values (i.e. their values during the first period of food security) during this period.

sample.value:
We will study a single flock of 6 adult starlings comprising 3 males and 3 females. 

To understand the effects of food insecurity, in the first instance, we will compare all observations collected from the first 7 days of food security with all observations from the full 14 days of food insecurity. 

Some variables are measured at the level of individual birds and others are only available at the flock level.

analyses.value:
Data will be analysed using the statistical programming language R. To test hypotheses relating to the effects of experimental condition we will use linear mixed models (LMMs) fitted using the R package ‘lme4’. We will specify appropriate random effects to account for sources of non-independence in the datasets. In all models, we will check the distribution of residuals and homogeneity of variance and transform data as appropriate. We will use restricted maximum likelihood estimation (REML) and conduct overall significance tests of treatment using type III ANOVA with Satterthwaite’s method. A criterion for significance of p < 0.05 will be assumed throughout.

Hypotheses 1-4 will be tested with the following analyses:
1.	Foraging effort
- Unit of analysis: number of pecks per bird per day
- Model: peck.rate ~ experimental.condition + (1|bird.ID)

2.	Competition for access to food
- Unit of analysis = number of displacements per bird per day
- Model: slope ~ experimental.condition + (1|bird.ID)

3.	Body mass at dawn and dusk:
- Unit of analysis = estimated mass per bird per day (separate models will be fitted for dawn and dusk mass)
- Model: body.mass ~ experimental.condition + (1|bird.ID)

4.	Relationship between rank and body mass gain
- Unit of analysis: David’s score and change in body mass under food insecurity per bird
- Model: mass.change ~ Davids.score

outliers.value: To estimate comparable dawn and dusk masses for each bird on each day we will use the following procedure. As long as a minimum of 10 masses ware available, the mass data from each bird-day will be fitted with a cubic polynomial. To remove biologically impossible outliers, any masses > 3 g from the fitted line will be removed and a new cubic polynomial was refitted to the remaining data. This latter model will be used to estimate dawn and dusk masses for that day at 8 am and 5 pm respectively. To avoid extrapolation beyond the data, a dawn or dusk mass will only be estimated if there is a data point within 1 hour of the estimate.

dependent.value:
•	Foraging effort (pecks/hr) will be measured by counting the number of key pecks a bird makes in a day.
•	Competition for access to food will be assessed by counting how often one bird displaces another from a feeding station, defined as one bird replacing another on a feeding station within 1 second.
•	Body mass (g) will be measured whenever a bird perches on a feeding station. A stable mass will be recorded for a bird if the balance measures five consecutive masses of > 50 g that were within a range of 5 g. 
•	Dominance rank will be calculated from the displacement data using David’s score.

conditions.value: A single flock of starlings housed in an aviary equipped with two operant feeding stations will be studied under two experimental conditions: probability of reinforcement = 1.0 (food security) and probability of reinforcement = 0.3 (food insecurity). We will use a within-subjects design with the birds experiencing 7 days of food security, followed by 14 days of food insecurity. Time permitting, the experiment will end with a further 7-9 days of food security.

hypothesis.value:
The aim of this study is to ask how reducing the probability of reinforcement in a closed-economy operant foraging task affects competition for access to food and body mass in a small flock of adult wild-caught European starlings (Sturnus vulgaris). 

We hypothesise that when the probability of reinforcement is reduced from 1.0 (food security) to 0.3 (food insecurity) the following changes will occur:
1.	The birds will increase their foraging effort 
2.	Competition between birds for access to foraging will increase
3.	The birds will increase their body mass
4.	The lower a bird’s rank in the dominance hierarchy, the more mass it will gain

attributes.title: Populism and the Principle Application gap

q1.value: Populism and the principle application gap

q4.value:
Main prediction: There will be a greater discrepancy between support for pluralism as an abstract concept and concrete support for pluralism (pertaining to a disliked group) among individuals who score high on populism.

Exploration: We will explore whether bullshit receptivity, epistemic simplicity, rational and intuitive thinking styles, and overconfidence in one's own knowledge mediate the effect of pluralism on support for pluralism.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We employ a between subjects design with two conditions and an additional continuous IV. In condition 1, participants will answer a set of questions designed to measure concrete support for pluralism pertaining to a disliked outgroup. In condition 2, on the other hand, participants will answer a set of questions designed to measure support for pluralism as an abstract concept. In addition, the participants will answer questions taken from a number of scales, measuring bullshit receptivity, epistemic simplicity, rational and intuitive thinking styles, and overconfidence in one's own knowledge. Furthermore, participants will answer questions of demographic nature.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The data will be collected from a convenience-sample of US-participants. Participants will be recruited through advertisements on Mturk. From there, they will be redirected to a Qualtrics survey. Participants will be paid $1.20 for participation.

q13.value: We will collect a sample of 300 subjects from the United States.

q14.value: Our sample implies on average 150 participants per condition, which yields 95% power to detect a small-to-medium effect size (f2 = .07, two-sided).

q15.value:
Data collection will be stopped once the set sample size is reached.
Variables

question.value:
- We measure basic demographics, notably gender, age, and education level.
- We measure the following main variables: Populism, Concrete Support for Pluralism pertaining to a Disliked Group, Support for Pluralism in the Abstract. (see the online appendix for specific items)
- We measure the following explorative variables: bullshit receptivity, need for simple solutions, rational and intuitive thinking styles, and overconfidence.

To our hypothesis, we conduct a hierarchical regression analysis controlling for gender, age, education, and political ideology in Step 1, the main effects of populist attitudes and condition in Step 2, and the populist attitudes x condition interaction in Step 3, with support for pluralism as DV. We will first center the populism scale and effect-code the conditions (-1 and +1).

Our hypothesis implies a significant interaction (p < .05). If we find it we will follow up with simple slopes analysis, in which we test the effect of condition at +1SD and -1SD of the populism scale. Our hypothesis implies that the condition effect is stronger at +1SD than -1SD.
We will also explore the populism effect in both conditions separately, and the possible mediating role of the various exploratory mediators.

q21.value: We will use two-tailed tests and the standard p < .05 criteria for each of our analyses.

Exploration: We will explore whether bullshit receptivity, epistemic simplicity, rational and intuitive thinking styles, and overconfidence in one's own knowledge mediate the effect of pluralism on support for pluralism.

We will first center the populism scale and effect-code the conditions (-1 and +1).

attributes.title: Teaching professionalism in medical residency programs: a scoping review protocol
attributes.description: This scoping review will try to search published methods of teaching professionalism for medical residents in the literature from 1st day of 2010 until last day 0f 2019.

q1.value: Teaching professionalism in medical residency programs: a scoping review protocol

q2.value: Saeideh Ghaffarifar, Azam Asghari Khatooni, Amirhossein Akbarzadeh, Ahmad Pourabbas, Mehran Seif Farshad, Fariborz Akbarzadeh

q3.value:
Professionalism is a core competency of medical residents in residency programs. Unprofessional behavior has a negative influence on patient safety, quality of care, and interpersonal relationships. The objective of this scoping review is to map the range of teaching methods of professionalism to medical residents in residency programs, Our objectives are to: 
•	Systematically explore literature focused on methods of teaching professionalism in medical residency programs.
•	Map the publications to classify teaching methods of professionalism based on various residency programs and various cultures like Asian, European, American, etc.
•	Merge our findings with findings of published systematic reviews (BEME and Berger’s) to map changes and trends in teachings methods of professionalism from the first day of 2010 up to the end of the year 2019.

q4.value: What teaching methods of professionalism in medical residency programs (in all specialties and in any setting, whether in secondary, primary or community care settings) have been reported?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: The researchers who extracting the data and review selected articles are unaware of the results of other reviewers

question.value: To achieve the purpose and objectives of this study we decided to use the scoping review method described by Arksey and O’Malley [18] and stages developed by Levac et al [19]. These studies suggested six steps to do scoping reviews. 1- Formulating the research question, 2- identifying relevant studies, 3- selecting the literature, 4- charting the data, 5- collecting, summarizing and reporting the results and 6- consultation that is an optional stage. In the following sections, we will describe every step of our scoping review.

q9.value: there a no randomization in this study

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: There are many articles in literature and databases about the teaching of professionalism to medical residents. This study finds to gather the presented articles to find methods of teaching of professionalism to medical residents and classify the results by residency programs and ethnic groups. The data will be qualitative data.

question.value:
Step 2: Identifying relevant studies
With the helping of the expert librarians in searching strategies. Parameters of our search strategy were defined. Based on the purpose and objectives of our scoping review, peer-reviewed and grey literature will be searched systematically. The search strategy will be explained in detail in the following paragraphs. We will use appropriate keywords and subject headings and their synonyms and equivalents to collect data as much as possible. Our systematic and comprehensive search will include:
A)	Electronic databases in the field of medicine, healthcare, health and other interdisciplinary databases including MEDLINE (through PubMed), Scopus, EMBASE, PsycINFO, Cochrane, and Web of Science will be searched. 
B)	We will search grey literature sources including websites of different associations for medical training such as "The International Association for Medical Education (AMEE)" [20], “ The Association for the Study of Medical Education(ASME)” [21], “World Federation for Medical Education(WFME)"[22] or ACGME (Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education) [23].  Dissertations and theses on ProQuest, GreyNet, and Google Scholar will be searched as well. 
C)	We will do hand searching of principal journals in the field of medical education and professionalism like a medical teacher; medical education; academic medicine; clinical teacher; and teaching and learning in medicine. 
D)	The references of selected articles in stages A, B and C will search manually. 
E)	We will contact authors of primary studies for clarification or missing information. Leading authors in the field of teaching professionalism will be contacted.
A wide variety of search terms, included MeSh terms, will use to search title and abstract of articles based on each data base search formula to obtain all published articles in the field of teaching professionalism. Our proposed search terms will be professionalism, medical ethics, ethical behavior, bioethics, professional role, medical education, medical teaching, medical training, educational method, teaching program, and teaching method, hospital teaching, education, teaching, educational program,  We will use PRESS checklist for peer review of our search strategies [24].

q13.value: This study will include all relevant studies for further analysis.

q14.value: No Sample size calculation is present in this study.

q15.value: There are no criteria for stopping the research.

question.value: This study don't want to manipulate variables.
Teaching methods of professionalism to medical residents, Residency program, ethnic group, types of evaluation of professionalism
No Statistical models are predicted for this study

q22.value:
-	Languages other than English
-	Nursing studies
-	Dentistry studies 
-	If applicable residency programs of medical groups other than medicine like as rehabilitation, physiotherapy, etc. who are not a medical doctor
-	Undergraduate medical students
-	Articles that have an only assessment of professionalism in their subjects
-	Continuous medical education (CME) studies
-	Personal development studies

•	Systematically explore literature focused on methods of teaching professionalism in medical residency programs.
•	Map the publications to classify teaching methods of professionalism based on various residency programs and various cultures like Asian, European, American, etc.
•	Merge our findings with findings of published systematic reviews (BEME and Berger’s) to map changes and trends in teachings methods of professionalism from the first day of 2010 up to the end of the year 2019.

-	Languages other than English
-	Nursing studies
-	Dentistry studies 
-	If applicable residency programs of medical groups other than medicine like as rehabilitation, physiotherapy, etc. who are not a medical doctor
-	Undergraduate medical students
-	Articles that have an only assessment of professionalism in their subjects
-	Continuous medical education (CME) studies
-	Personal development studies
registration_responses.q8.question: To achieve the purpose and objectives of this study we decided to use the scoping review method described by Arksey and O’Malley [18] and stages developed by Levac et al [19]. These studies suggested six steps to do scoping reviews. 1- Formulating the research question, 2- identifying relevant studies, 3- selecting the literature, 4- charting the data, 5- collecting, summarizing and reporting the results and 6- consultation that is an optional stage. In the following sections, we will describe every step of our scoping review.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Step 2: Identifying relevant studies
With the helping of the expert librarians in searching strategies. Parameters of our search strategy were defined. Based on the purpose and objectives of our scoping review, peer-reviewed and grey literature will be searched systematically. The search strategy will be explained in detail in the following paragraphs. We will use appropriate keywords and subject headings and their synonyms and equivalents to collect data as much as possible. Our systematic and comprehensive search will include:
A)	Electronic databases in the field of medicine, healthcare, health and other interdisciplinary databases including MEDLINE (through PubMed), Scopus, EMBASE, PsycINFO, Cochrane, and Web of Science will be searched. 
B)	We will search grey literature sources including websites of different associations for medical training such as "The International Association for Medical Education (AMEE)" [20], “ The Association for the Study of Medical Education(ASME)” [21], “World Federation for Medical Education(WFME)"[22] or ACGME (Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education) [23].  Dissertations and theses on ProQuest, GreyNet, and Google Scholar will be searched as well. 
C)	We will do hand searching of principal journals in the field of medical education and professionalism like a medical teacher; medical education; academic medicine; clinical teacher; and teaching and learning in medicine. 
D)	The references of selected articles in stages A, B and C will search manually. 
E)	We will contact authors of primary studies for clarification or missing information. Leading authors in the field of teaching professionalism will be contacted.
A wide variety of search terms, included MeSh terms, will use to search title and abstract of articles based on each data base search formula to obtain all published articles in the field of teaching professionalism. Our proposed search terms will be professionalism, medical ethics, ethical behavior, bioethics, professional role, medical education, medical teaching, medical training, educational method, teaching program, and teaching method, hospital teaching, education, teaching, educational program,  We will use PRESS checklist for peer review of our search strategies [24].
registration_responses.q16.question: This study don't want to manipulate variables.
registration_responses.q17.question: Teaching methods of professionalism to medical residents, Residency program, ethnic group, types of evaluation of professionalism

attributes.title: The Role of Metacognitions in Differentiation Dementia and Depression in the Population of Sixty Years and Over
